title: A Spac ménage à trois gets messy for private equity
text:
Welcome to Due Diligence, your briefing on dealmaking, private equity and corporate finance from the Financial Times. Want to receive DD in your inbox? Sign up here. Get in touch with us anytime: Due.Diligence@ft.com.

It's complicated: private equity awaits its fate in the Dyal/Owl Rock deal

At first, the audacious bid to take Dyal Capital and Owl Rock public prompted confusion on Wall Street. Now, there is real anger — and some heavyweight companies are preparing for a battle royale.

In a complex deal, a shell company sponsored by HPS Investment Partners intends to merge with two of Wall Street biggest recent success stories. 

One of them, Dyal, has in the past decade become the partner of choice for big-name private equity groups looking to sell stakes in their business; it has snapped up pieces of Silver Lake and Vista, at huge valuations.

The other, Owl Rock, is an up-and-coming direct lender — which puts it in competition with a number of companies that have sold stakes to Dyal. 

Two of Owl Rock's rivals think the fit is outrageous. Sixth Street Partners and Golub Capital have in the past week taken their claims of betrayal to court. 

Both believe that the merged group, to be called Blue Owl, will be an arch-competitor of theirs — and worse, a competitor that will be privy to some of their most intimate secrets. And they argue that their contracts with Dyal give them the right to stop the Spac deal.

Naturally, Dyal, founded by former Lehman Brothers bankers Michael Rees and Sean Ward, disagrees. It will contest the lawsuits, which have been filed in state courts in Delaware and New York.

The deal valued Blue Owl at a juicy $12.5bn, putting it in the league of the likes of Ares Management and Carlyle Group. It's also a sweet deal for Dyal's owner, asset manager Neuberger Berman. Neuberger, also once a part of the Lehman empire, is to net more than $1bn in proceeds — while remaining a large holder of Blue Owl. 

That payout depends, of course, on the deal closing. Now, litigation in two jurisdictions has muddled the path forward — and some of the most secretive and powerful financial groups in the world may soon be airing their dirty laundry in court. 

McKinsey's Sneader packs his things

Well, we warned you things were going to get ugly at McKinsey. 

The consultancy's global managing partner Kevin Sneader has been voted out by its 650 senior partners, in a historic rebuke over his handling of a string of crises, according to this scoop from DD's Arash Massoudi and the FT's Andrew Hill and Andrew Edgecliffe-Johnson.

That means the top job could fall to Bob Sternfels or Sven Smit, two senior partners based in San Francisco and Amsterdam respectively, who have made it through to the last round of the leadership election. A final vote is expected in the next week or two.

Though part of a routine process, the vote was seen by many as a referendum on how the 54-year-old Scot had responded to the numerous scandals he faced when he took the helm in 2018 — the firm's entanglement in the opioid crisis being just one among many.

The voting results were unusual, even with the odds stacked against him from the beginning. His five predecessors served at least two terms, and their reappointments were often uncontested.

The final count could reflect the growing influence of a younger generation of partners making waves within the 30,000-strong firm. “An incumbent managing partner has so many advantages [over challengers] that clearly a substantial group [of partners] felt very unhappy,” one McKinsey alum told DD.

But Sneader's exit doesn't mean McKinsey will automatically reclaim its legendary “mystique”.

The scent of scandal jeopardising its reputation with clients and recruits will fade with time, as Lex points out, but to make substantial change, the consultancy will need to overhaul a culture that has steered it wrong so many times before.

India: the next Spac frontier

Robert Mancini, a former Carlyle Group dealmaker who helped run its power infrastructure business, is headed east to chase a new kind of energy source that's been electrifying Wall Street of late. We're talking about Spacs, of course.

Mancini's RMG Acquisition Corporation II, a special purpose acquisition vehicle backed by Goldman Sachs, BlackRock, and de facto “Spac king” Chamath Palihapitiya, has struck a deal to take ReNew Power, one of India's largest renewable energy groups, public in New York.

“We were approached and when we looked at it, it seemed to make a lot of sense, the process went very fast,” Sumant Sinha, the energy company's chief executive, told the FT's Stephanie Findlay.

More deals are likely to emerge just as quickly as US Spacs hunt for overseas targets — and there's no shortage of options from India's more than 30 unicorns nearing valuations of $1bn or above. For the targets, Spacs pose a cheaper and faster route to a foreign listing.

Raj Balakrishnan, head of India investment banking at Bank of America, is busy at work on “multiple” transactions with Spacs in the $200m to $1bn range, he told Stephanie.

Let the games begin.

Job moves

Two big job moves resulting from the Wirecard fallout:

  • Edgar Ernst, the president of Germany's Financial Reporting Enforcement Panel, will step down following mounting political pressure over corporate governance shortcomings exposed by the Wirecard fraud.

  • Jana Hecker, a senior investment banker who acted as a financial adviser to former Wirecard boss Markus Braun has left her job at UniCredit following revelations about the business relationship. 

Houlihan Lokey has appointed Andreas Dombret as independent chairman of its activities in Germany, Austria, and Switzerland. He was previously a senior adviser to the firm.

Bank of America has appointed Luca Ferrari, who currently co-heads M&A for Europe, Middle East and Africa alongside Eamon Brabazon, to M&A chairman across the Emea regions. He is succeeded by the bank's current head of M&A for Germany, Austria and Switzerland, Birger Berendes.

BNP Paribas has hired Panos Metsis as a managing director on its telecoms, media and technology team. He joins from Akira Partners.

Smart reads

The sound of money Music's most infamous dealmaker Merck Mercuriadis is raising billions from investors to amass a mega collection of hits. But question marks linger as to the true value of his platinum playlists. (Forbes)

Force of nature Salesforce and its eccentric founder Marc Benioff are everywhere. The software company recently dropped $28bn on Slack, and its technology underpins a seemingly infinite list of companies. But what is it, really? (Slate + Thrilling Tales of Modern Capitalism podcast)
